trans-unit.source: Represents a standard Windows vertical scroll bar.
Most controls that need scroll bars already provide them and do not require this control.
This is true of a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListBox>, and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox>, for example.
You can use this control to implement scrolling in containers that do not provide their own scroll bars such as a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PictureBox> or for user input of numeric data.
The numeric data can be displayed in a control or used in code.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Minimum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.Maximum%2A> properties determine the range of values the user can select.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.LargeChange%2A> property determines the effect of clicking within the scroll bar but outside the scroll box.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ScrollBar.SmallChange%2A> property determines the effect of clicking the scroll arrows at each end of the control.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar"></xref> class.
Gets the required creation parameters when the control handle is created.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams"></xref> that contains the required creation parameters when the handle to the control is created.
Gets the default size of the control.
The default <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> of the control.
Gets a value indicating whether control's elements are aligned to support locales using right-to-left fonts.
The RightToLeft property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> control cannot be set.
Occurs when the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar.RightToLeft*> property changes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar.RightToLeft%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> control cannot be set, so the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.VScrollBar> never raises the RightToLeftChanged event.
